content.explanation:
Every parabola has a line of symmetry that passes through its vertex. This line is called the axis of symmetry.

For a quadratic function f(x) = ax² + bx + c, the axis of symmetry is the vertical line:

x = -b/(2a)

This is the same as the x-coordinate of the vertex. If you fold the graph along this line, the two halves of the parabola match exactly.
content.example:
For the function f(x) = 2x² - 8x + 7:
- The x-coordinate of the vertex is x = -(-8)/(2(2)) = 8/4 = 2
- The axis of symmetry is the vertical line x = 2
- Points equidistant from this line have the same y-value, e.g., f(1) = f(3)
content.key_point: The axis of symmetry helps us understand the behavior of the parabola. For any point on the parabola, there's a corresponding point on the other side of the axis with the same height.
